> -----Original Message-----
> From: Ilja Preuss [mailto:preuss@...] 
> areider wrote:
> 
> > I think we are coming from different places. Maybe its my Smalltalk 
> > background.
> 
> Probably not. As far as I know, the original framework was SUnit (for
> Smalltalk) and JUnit is more or less a port to Java.
> 

I gave a talk called "Testing Smalltalk Applications" at the Smalltalk
Solutions conference in '98 and '99 which included a few words on the
benefit of converting 'doit' code into test cases, so this is certainly
(in my mind) a valid approach, although it might be a foreign one to
anyone who is not used to the ability to type and execute snippets of
code within an IDE. 

I still think that moving the workspace/scrapbook code into methods that
return values is fine. You can then call them from JUnit style test
methods that assert(...) things about the returned values. Then you get
your methods in the form you want and can use JUnit for its ability to
catalog and automatically execute tests, as well as assert and log state
where it is appropriate.
